chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Most people can agree that a president should win through broad national support, and that the rules should be predictable, auditable, and not dependent on a handful of battleground states. A workable compromise is to keep the Electoral College but change how states award electors—using proportional allocation with a meaningful minimum threshold—paired with stronger national standards for vote counting, recounts, and certification. That approach preserves the state-based structure while making outcomes track the popular will more closely and reducing incentives to ignore voters in “safe” states.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Even when we disagree about keeping or replacing the Electoral College, most people want a presidential election that feels fair, transparent, and legitimate—and that pushes candidates to build support beyond a handful of battlegrounds. A practical bridge is to reduce winner-take-all distortions by awarding electors proportionally or through a uniform district method with anti-gerrymandering safeguards, while also strengthening uniform national standards for counting, recounts, and resolving disputes. Alongside these steps, states can seriously evaluate a coordinated compact approach to better align the final outcome with the national popular will without requiring an immediate all-or-nothing constitutional overhaul.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Even when we disagree on keeping or replacing the Electoral College, most people want a president chosen by rules that feel fair, easy to understand, and hard to manipulate—and that don’t make most states or voters feel irrelevant. A practical compromise is to keep the constitutional framework but reduce winner-take-all distortions by moving to proportional (or carefully designed district) allocation with strong anti-gerrymandering safeguards, while also adopting clearer national standards for counting, recounts, and disputed results. We can judge any change by shared tests: does it make every vote matter more, encourage campaigning beyond a few swing states, and produce outcomes people will accept even when their side loses?
